questions.question: Which enzyme is considered the rate-limiting step in galactose metabolism?
questions.explanation: metabolism. Galactose Metabolism : Dietary Source Lactose in milk and milk products. Structure Aldohexose and it is the 4th epimer of glucose. Metabolism Site Metabolized exclusively by the liver . Therefore, galactose tolerance tests can assess liver function. Galactose Metabolism : 1) Phosphorylation Galactose is phosphorylated by galactokinase to form galactose-1-phosphate. (Option A ruled out) ATP is the phosphate donor. 2) Uridine diphosphate-galactose (UDP-galactose) formation Galactose-1-phosphate converts to UDP-galactose and glucose-1-phosphate via an exchange reaction with UDP-glucose The reaction is catalyzed by Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT : rate-limiting enzyme in galactose metabolism) (Option B ruled out) 3) UDP-galactose conversion to UDP-glucose UDP-galactose is isomerized to UDP-glucose by UDP-hexose-4-epimerase. (Option C ruled out) The new UDP-glucose can enter biosynthetic reactions (e.g., glycogenesis) and the GALT reaction. 4) UDP-galactose in biosynthetic reactions UDP-galactose serves as an active donor of galactose for synthesizing lactose, glycoproteins, glycolipids and glycosaminoglycans. If dietary galactose is unavailable, UDP-galactose can be synthesized from UDP-glucose via UDP-hexose-4-epimerase. Aldolase reductase (Option D)- reduces galactose to galactitol and glucose to sorbitol. It is not the rate-limiting of galactose metabolism

questions.question: An infant is diagnosed with classic galactosemia. Which enzyme deficiency is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: which galactose-1-phosphate and, therefore, galactose accumulate. Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyl transferase (GALT) Deficiency Severely deficient in individuals with Classic Galactosemia in which galactose-1-phosphate and, therefore, galactose accumulate. (Option B) It Is an inborn error of metabolism Accumulation Accumulated galactose is shunted into side pathways like galactitol production. Aldose reductase catalyzes it. Galactose-1-phosphate accumulates in the liver, inhibiting galactokinase and glycogen phosphorylase, leading to hypoglycemia. Bilirubin Reduced bilirubin uptake and conjugation, increasing unconjugated bilirubin in blood Symptoms Hypoglycemia, hypophosphatemia, hyperuricemia, lactic acidosis Hepatomegaly, jaundice, Severe mental retardation Galactosuria (galactose excreted in urine) Cataracts due to dulcitol accumulation in the lens Tubular damage and generalized aminoaciduria Diagnosis Clinical manifestations (e.g., congenital cataract), presence of galactose in urine and elevated blood galactose levels Prenatal diagnosis via amniocentesis Detection of heterozygous parents by elevated galactose levels after a galactose load Complications in untreated cases E. coli sepsis, Fanconi syndrome Feeding problems, Failure to thrive, Hepatocellular damage, Bleeding Treatment Withdrawal of galactose and lactose from the diet. GALT deficiency is a part of the newborn screening panel Galactokinase (Option A) phosphorylate galactose to form galactose 1-phosphate. Its deficiency leads to less severe disorder of galactose metabolism (Benign Galactosemia). UDP-hexose-4-epimerase (Option C) isomerises UDP-galactose to UDP-glucose. Its deficiency leads to a less severe disorder of galactose metabolism. Aldolase reductase (Option D) reduces galactose to galactitol and glucose to sorbitol.

questions.question: A child is diagnosed with essential fructosuria during a routine health check. Name the enzyme A responsible for this condition
questions.explanation: Metabolism : Dietary Source Found in fruits, honey, and high-fructose corn syrup Structure Ketohexose Metabolism Site Primarily metabolized by the liver Fructose Metabolism : 1) Phosphorylation: Fructokinase is the primary enzyme for fructose phosphorylation. It has a high affinity (low Km) and a high Vmax for fructose. It converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate using ATP. It is found in the liver, kidneys, and small intestine . 2) Fructose 1-Phosphate Cleavage: Aldolase B c leaves fructose 1-phosphate to dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP) and glyceraldehyde. It is present in the liver, kidneys, and small intestine. DHAP enters glycolysis or gluconeogenesis. Glyceraldehyde is metabolized through various pathways. Disorders of Fructose Metabolism 1) Essential Fructosuria: Benign metabolic disorder Caused by fructokinase deficiency Excretion of fructose in urine Low risk of cataracts as aldose reductase does not act on fructose, and sorbitol dehydrogenase has low affinity for it. 2) Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI): Caused by aldolase B deficiency. (Option A ruled out) Symptoms appear when infants consume sucrose or fructose. Effects are due to accumulation of fructose 1-phosphate. Symptoms: Vomiting, appetite loss, failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, jaundice, potential liver damage and death Diagnosis: Detection of fructose in urine, enzyme assay using liver cells or DNA-based testing. Treatment: Remove sucrose, sorbitol and fructose from the diet. Hexokinase (Option B) – This enzyme is involved in the initial phosphorylation of glucose, not fructose. Hexokinase can phosphorylate fructose to fructose-6-phosphate, but it does not cause the specific symptoms seen in essential fructosuria. Therefor Hexokinase is not the enzyme responsible for essential fructosuria. Glucokinase (Option D) – This enzyme is involved in glucose metabolism and is primarily found in the liver and pancreas. It is not involved in the metabolism of fructose. Therefore, Glucokinase is not relevant to essential fructosuria.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI) and Classical Galactosemia?

options.B: Both require lifelong avoidance of lactose.
options.D: Both have symptoms that appear at birth.

questions.explanation: accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate in the liver, kidneys, and intestines. The buildup of fructose-1-phosphate interferes with phosphate metabolism, leading to a decrease in available phosphate, resulting in hypophosphatemia. Classical Galactosemia: In Classical Galactosemia, the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) is deficient. This leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate. Similar to HFI, the accumulated galactose-1-phosphate also interferes with phosphate metabolism, causing hypophosphatemia. Feature Hereditary Fructose Intolerance Classical Galactosemia Enzyme Deficiency Aldolase B Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) Onset (Option D ruled out) Symptoms appear when sucrose/ fructose is introduced into the diet (around 6 months of age) Initial signs usually present in the first few weeks of life Accumulated Metabolite Fructose-1-phosphate Galactose-1-phosphate and galactose Symptoms (Option A ruled out) (Option C) Hypoglycemia, h ypophosphatemia, hyperuricemia, lactic acidosis Hepatomegaly, jaundice, Vomiting, Loss of appetite, Failure to thrive. Aldose reductase cannot act on fructose (very low risk of cataract) Hypoglycemia, hypophosphatemia, hyperuricemia, lactic acidosis, Hepatomegaly, jaundice, Severe mental retardation, Galactosuria, Cataracts Diagnosis Presence of fructose in urine, enzyme assay or by DNA-based testing Clinical manifestations, elevated blood galactose levels; amniocentesis for prenatal diagnosis Urinary Findings Positive Benedict’s test for fructose Positive Benedict’s test for galactose Dietary Management (Option B ruled out) Sucrose, sorbitol and fructose must be removed from the diet Galactose and lactose must be removed from the diet Complication in untreated cases Renal failure, Hepatic failure, Seizures, Progressive coma E. coli sepsis, Feeding problems, Failure to thrive, Hepatocellular damage. Note: Benedict’s test is positive for reducing sugars. Seliwanoff’s test/ Rapid furfural test is specific for Fructose. Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry Edition 7 page no:423,424,430 Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry Edition 32 Page no: 199,200 Textbook of Biochem by DM Vasudevan Edition 7 page no:138,139,140 https://www.childrenshospital.org/conditions/galactosemia https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1518/

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue and pallor. Blood tests reveal hemolytic anemia. On further investigation, it is found that his erythrocytes are susceptible to oxidative damage. What is the primary role of the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) that is deficient in this patient’s RBCs?

options.A: To produce ATP for energy metabolism
options.B: To generate ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis
options.C: To provide NADPH for maintaining reduced glutathione levels

questions.explanation: NADPH is crucial for maintaining glutathione in its reduced form, which is necessary for the activity of glutathione peroxidase. This enzyme removes harmful hydrogen peroxide (H I O I ), protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage and preventing hemolysis. Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP) The Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP), also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP shunt), is an alternative metabolic pathway for glucose that doesn't generate ATP. Location: Cytosol It serves two primary functions: NADPH Production The PPP is a major source of NADPH, vital for biosynthesis (fatty acids and steroids). NADPH Production: RBCs rely on glycolysis for ATP due to the lack of mitochondria and depend solely on the PPP for NADPH, as they lack mitochondrial dehydrogenases. Glutathione Maintenance: NADPH keeps glutathione reduced, enabling glutathione peroxidase to neutralise hydrogen peroxide and prevent oxidative damage. Impact of NADPH Deficiency : Low NADPH impairs glutathione peroxidase, increases oxidative damage , and leads to hemolysis . Ribose-5-Phosphate (R-5-P) Synthesis Ribose-5-phosphate is essential for nucleotide synthesis needed for RNA and DNA. Homeostasis between NADPH and R-5-P production. When NADPH demand exceeds R-5-P's need, the non-oxidative phase converts R-5-P to glycolytic intermediates (fructose-6-phosphate and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate). If the demand for R-5-P is higher than for NADPH, the non-oxidative phase generates R-5-P from fructose-6-phosphate and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate, bypassing the oxidative steps. Differences from Glycolysis Uses NADP+ instead of NAD+ and generates CO2, not ATP. To produce ATP for energy metabolism (Option A): While RBCs do require ATP, their primary energy source is glycolysis. The PPP is not a major ATP-producing pathway. To generate ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis (Option B): Ribose-5-phosphate is a product of the PPP and is essential for nucleotide synthesis. However, mature RBCs lack a nucleus and do not synthesize nucleotides. Therefore this is not the primary function in mature RBCs. To synthesize haemoglobin (Option D): Haemoglobin synthesis occurs during RBC development in the bone marrow, not through the PPP.

questions.question: Which sequence correctly represents the steps of the oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP)? → Glucose-6-phosphate → 6-Phosphogluconate → Ribulose-5-phosphate → 6-Phosphogluconate → 6-Phosphogluconolactone → Ribulose-5-phosphate → 6-Phosphogluconolactone → 6-Phosphogluconate → Ribulose-5-phosphate → 6-Phosphogluconolactone → Glucose-6-phosphate → Ribulose-5-phosphate
questions.explanation: → 6-Phosphogluconolactone → 6-Phosphogluconate → Ribulose-5-phosphate and converting glucose-6-phosphate to ribulose-5-phosphate. Step Substrates Enzyme Products 1 Glucose-6-phosphate + NADP+ Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase 6-Phosphogluconolactone + NADPH 2 6-Phosphogluconolactone Gluconolactone hydrolase 6-Phosphogluconate 3 6-Phosphogluconate + NADP+ 6-Phosphogluconate dehydrogenase Ribulose-5-phosphate + NADPH + CO2 Overall Reaction: Glucose-6-phosphate + 2 NADP+ + H I O → Ribulose-5-phosphate + 2 NADPH + 2 H I + CO I Fate of products: NADPH: The two molecules of NADPH produced in this phase are essential for various biosynthetic pathways, such as fatty acid synthesis and steroid synthesis. Ribulose-5-Phosphate: Used for nucleotide synthesis or converted to other sugars for glycolysis or gluconeogenesis. Reference: Harper’s IllusBiochemistry 32ed Pg 193-194

questions.question: Which statement is true regarding NADH and NADPH?

options.A: Both are produced in the Pentose Phosphate Pathway.
options.B: NADH is used in lipid biosynthesis, while NADPH is not.
options.C: NADPH is used for anabolic reactions, while NADH is primarily for catabolic reactions.
options.D: Both serve the same functions in the cell.

questions.explanation: reactions. respiration where it functions as an electron carrier, transferring electrons to the electron transport chain to produce ATP. NADPH: Primarily involved in anabolic reactions, such as fatty acid and nucleotide synthesis, and in maintaining the reducing environment of the cell by donating electrons. NADPH Role and Function: Feature NADH NADPH Full Name Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide (reduced). Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide Phosphate (reduced). Primary Role Energy production, electron transport. Reductive biosynthesis, maintaining reduced states. Pathways Primarily generated in catabolic pathways: Citric Acid Cycle, Glycolysis, Fatty Acid oxidation. Primarily generated in anabolic pathways: Pentose Phosphate Pathway, Malic Enzyme Reaction, Oxidative Decarboxylation - Isoforms of Isocitrate Dehydrogenase. Key Functions Donates electrons to the Electron Transport Chain (ETC) for ATP production. The ETC uses NADH for ATP production, yielding 2.5 ATPs. Donates electrons & provides reducing power for biosynthetic reactions (reductive biosynthesis) like lipid and nucleotide synthesis. Maintains reduced glutathione (G-SH) in RBCs, preventing oxidative damage. Regenerates reduced glutathione (G-SH) from its oxidized form. It is not involved in ATP generation via the ETC. Production Site Mitochondria (mainly), Cytosol Cytosol (mainly), some in mitochondria and plastids Both are produced in the Pentose Phosphate Pathway (Option A): This is only partially true. NADPH is a key product of the pentose phosphate pathway. NADH is produced in other metabolic pathways, like glycolysis and the citric acid cycle. NADH is used in lipid biosynthesis, while NADPH is not. (Option B): This is incorrect. NADPH is essential for lipid biosynthesis, providing the necessary reducing power.NADH has a minimal role in that process. Both serve the same functions in the cell. (Option D): This is incorrect. While both are electron carriers, their main purposes and locations of work within the cell, differ greatly. Reference: Harper’s Biochemistry 32nd Edition, Pg 87,117,194-195,228,342 Lippincott Illustrated Reviews: Biochemistry 7th Edition: Page: 129

questions.question: All the following enzymes catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions except? A. α -Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
questions.explanation: producing NADH but not releasing CO2. This is an oxidation reaction, not an oxidative decarboxylation. Malate + NAD + → Oxaloacetate + NADH + H + Enzymes that catalyse oxidative decarboxylation reaction: Enzyme Reaction (Oxidative decarboxylation of) Cofactors Details Pyruvate Dehydrogenase (PDH) Pyruvate to acetyl-CoA Thiamin diphosphate, lipoate, NAD+, FAD, CoA Converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in mitochondria Similar to the α -ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex Regulated by end-product inhibition and covalent modification. α -Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase ( α KGDH) (Option A ruled out) α -ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA Similar to the PDH complex; Equilibrium favors succinyl-CoA formation; Inhibited by arsenite. Isocitrate Dehydrogenase (IDH) (Option D ruled out) Isocitrate to α -ketoglutarate Mg 2+ or Mn 2+ ions Forms oxalosuccinate, which then decarboxylates; Part of the citric acid cycle. 6-Phosphogluconate Dehydrogenase (6-PGDH) (Option C ruled out) 6-phosphogluconate to ribulose-5-phosphate NADP + Catalyzes a reaction in the pentose phosphate pathway. Branched-Chain Ketoacid Dehydrogenase (BCKADH) Decarboxylation of branched-chain keto acids Thiamin pyrophosphate (TPP), lipoate, NAD + , FAD, CoA Similar to the PDH complex; Defects cause maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry Pg: 159,168,193,298

questions.question: Which of the following enzymes is not involved in the reversible phase of the pentose phosphate pathway?
questions.explanation: while the nonoxidative phase is known as the reversible phase. 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase is part of the oxidative phase and catalyzes the conversion of 6-phosphogluconate to Ribulose-5-phosphate. Substrate Enzyme Products Ribulose-5-phosphate Ribulose-5-phosphate 3- Epimerase (Option A ruled out) Xylulose-5-phosphate Ribulose-5-phosphate Ribose-5-phosphate ketoisomerase Ribose-5-phosphate Xylulose-5-phosphate + Ribose-5-phosphate Transketolase (Option B ruled out) Cofactor: Mg² I , Thiamin diphosphate (Vitamin B1) Sedoheptulose-7-phosphate + Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate Sedoheptulose-7-phosphate + Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate Transaldolase (Option A ruled out) Fructose-6-phosphate + Erythrose-4-phosphate Xylulose-5-phosphate + Erythrose-4-phosphate Transketolase (second reaction) Fructose-6-phosphate + Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate Regenerating Glucose-6-Phosphate: Two glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate molecules combine to form one fructose-6-phosphate (reversing step 4 of glycolysis). Fructose-6-phosphate is then converted back to glucose-6-phosphate (reversing step 2 of glycolysis). Thiamine deficiency: Transketolase requires thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) as a coenzyme. Thiamine deficiency impairs transketolase activity. RBCs rely on the pentose phosphate pathway for NADPH. Low RBC transketolase activity can indicate thiamine deficiency.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, living in a malaria-prone area, presents with fatigue, jaundice, dark urine, and recent consumption of fava beans. Lab tests show hemolytic anemia. How does glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency lead to the observed symptoms?

options.A: Reduced NADPH impairs glutathione regeneration, causing hemolytic anemia.
options.B: Increased ribulose-5-phosphate overloads nucleotides, leading to renal failure.
options.C: Impaired glucose-6-phosphate conversion disrupts glycolysis, causing hypoglycemia.
options.D: Decreased ATP production affects muscle function, causing myopathy.

questions.explanation: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is an enzyme involved in the pentose phosphate pathway , which is crucial for producing NADPH . NADPH is necessary to regenerate glutathione , a potent antioxidant that helps protect red blood cells (RBCs) from oxidative damage. In individuals with G6PD deficiency , there is insufficient NADPH production. This makes the RBCs more vulnerable to oxidative stress, such as that caused by fava beans , which contain compounds that can trigger oxidative damage. Without enough NADPH to counteract this stress, RBCs are damaged, leading to hemolysis (destruction of red blood cells). As a result of hemolysis, the patient may experience fatigue , jaundice (due to the release of bilirubin from the breakdown of red blood cells), and dark urine (from the presence of hemoglobin or bilirubin in the urine). Increased ribulose-5-phosphate overloads nucleotides, leading to renal failure (Option B): While ribulose-5-phosphate is a product of the PPP, its accumulation does not directly lead to renal failure. The primary issue in G6PD deficiency is the lack of NADPH and the resulting oxidative damage. Impaired glucose-6-phosphate conversion disrupts glycolysis, causing hypoglycemia (Option C): While G6PD deficiency affects glucose-6-phosphate, it does not significantly disrupt glycolysis to cause hypoglycemia. The primary issue is oxidative stress, not energy deficiency. Decreased ATP production affects muscle function, causing myopathy (Option D): While ATP is important, the PPP is not a major ATP-producing pathway in RBCs. The primary problem is the lack of NADPH and the resulting oxidative damage to the red blood cells.

questions.question: What is the role of inosine monophosphate in stored blood?

options.A: It increases plasma Na and K levels.

questions.explanation: cells that affects hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen. It binds to hemoglobin, decreasing its affinity for oxygen, which means oxygen is more readily released to tissues. In stored blood, 2,3-DPG levels decline over time. This results in increased hemoglobin affinity for oxygen and impaired oxygen delivery to tissues. Inosine Monophosphate (IMP): IMP is a purine nucleotide. In stored blood, IMP can be metabolized by red blood cells to regenerate 2,3-DPG. This helps to maintain adequate 2,3-DPG levels, ensuring that transfused red blood cells can effectively deliver oxygen to tissues. Inosine Monophosphate (IMP) is Hypoxanthine + Ribose Inosine in Stored Blood : Inosine stimulates 2,3-DPG synthesis, by getting converted to ribose-1-phosphate and hypoxanthine. (Option B) Ribose-1-phosphate is isomerized to ribose-5-phosphate and enters the pentose phosphate pathway, and is recycled back to fructose-6-phosphate or glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (GA3P). GA3P is converted to 1,3-diphosphoglycerate (1,3-DPG) in the presence of GA3P dehydrogenase and NAD. 1,3-DPG is converted to either 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) or 3-phosphoglycerate 2,3 DPG enhances oxygen delivery to tissues. Blood low in 2,3-DPG shifts the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve left, reducing oxygen delivery. Reconstitution of 2,3-DPG is rapid, but normalization takes days. Inosine does not retard changes in plasma Na, K, Hb, lactic acid, dextrose, or pH during storage. It increases plasma Na and K levels (Option A): IMP's primary function is related to red blood cell metabolism, specifically 2,3-DPG. It does not directly influence plasma sodium or potassium levels. Electrolyte balance is maintained by other mechanisms, and IMP is not involved in that. It prevents lactic acid buildup (Option C): Lactic acid buildup in stored blood is a consequence of anaerobic glycolysis due to glucose metabolism. While IMP plays a role in red blood cell metabolism, it does not directly prevent lactic acid accumulation. Other additives in stored blood, like citrate, help to mitigate this by preventing coagulation and slightly altering pH. It stabilizes hemoglobin concentration (Option D): Hemoglobin concentration in stored blood is primarily determined by the initial blood collection and processing. IMP's role is to improve the functional capacity of hemoglobin (oxygen delivery), not to stabilize its concentration.

questions.question: A patient with diabetes presents with vision impairment. Upon examination, snowflake cataracts are observed. The absence of which enzyme in certain tissues leads to sorbitol accumulation, resulting in conditions such as snowflake cataracts?
questions.explanation: tissues like the retina and lens leads to sorbitol accumulation, causing osmotic stress and cellular swelling, resulting in snowflake cataracts in diabetic patients. Hyperglycemia and Sorbitol Accumulation: Occurs in diabetes due to chronic high blood sugar. Excess glucose enters insulin-independent cells (retina, lens, kidneys, peripheral nerves). Aldose reductase activity increases, leading to more sorbitol production. Sorbitol dehydrogenase enzyme is absent in the eye hence sorbitol cannot be broken down further. Consequences of Sorbitol Accumulation: Osmotic Stress: Sorbitol gets trapped inside cells, causing water influx and cell swelling and cataract Formation. Tissue-Specific Enzyme Presence: Present: Liver: Sorbitol to fructose conversion, enters glycolysis. Ovaries: Sorbitol dehydrogenase present. Seminal Vesicles: Sorbitol dehydrogenase provides energy (fructose) for sperm cells. Absent: Retina, Lens, Kidneys, Peripheral Nerves: Have aldose reductase but lack sorbitol dehydrogenase, leading to sorbitol accumulation. Aldose Reductase (Option A) converts glucose to sorbitol. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (Option B) is a part of the pentose phosphate pathway and does not play a direct role in the sorbitol pathway. Hexokinase (Option D): Catalyses the first step of glycolysis and is not involved in the sorbitol pathway. Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Review of Bioc - Chapter 12. II. FRUCTOSE METABOLISM

questions.question: A newborn presents with bilateral lens opacities and decreased visual acuity. On examination, the characteristic "oil droplet" appearance is noted in the lens on retro illumination. Which metabolic disorder is primarily associated with developing oil-drop cataracts in newborns?
questions.explanation: defect in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase. This leads to the accumulation of galactitol, which causes osmotic stress and the characteristic “oil drop’’ cataracts. Oil Drop Cataracts and Galactosemia: Galactosemia is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase, impairing galactose metabolism. Characteristics Appearance: Distinct "oil droplet" look on retro illumination due to dulcitol accumulation. Symptoms: Decreased visual acuity, lenticular myopia, potential total lens opacification. Pathophysiology The inability to convert galactose to glucose leads to the buildup of galactitol. Affects lens transparency, causing cataracts shortly after birth. Management and Treatment Dietary Restrictions: Eliminate all sources of galactose (milk, dairy) to prevent progression. Surgical
